content: Just in case you don't notice it: https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-sparse-matmul-puzzle-discussion/205405/6 . Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting optimization problem, difficulty level is appropriate. Thanks!"
Hi, in the input section, on line 1, we expect M, N, and P in that order. However, in the stub generator section, N is listed as the first value. Where am I wrong?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I especially like it when a puzzle has some educational value. 
Both "sparse matrices" and "matrix multiplication" are topics valuable to learn about for beginners.

Expecting the results to be printed as "8.0" instead of 8 if it is integer is a bit obscure imho. (I know it comes from the quirkiness of  Python, but still.) 
Even expecting a fixed number of digits after the . would be better.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Figured it out with C# no problem.

Stub generator
* As the default code uses `i` as the variable for looping (at least in Python, maybe other languages as well), it will conflict with your `i` which is used for reading the [[row]] values.

[ e.g. the default code includes this:
  for i in range(a): … i = int(inputs[0]) ]

Goal
* If you are referring to this very website, then please change "Codingame" to "CodinGame". Otherwise, ignore this point.

Output
* Please mention that [[value]] should be unrounded and have all its significant digits shown, or with 1 zero after the decimal point if [[value]] is an integer.

(Note: I can't make this comment on the contribution in its WIP stage because the cases have not been finalised.)

Thanks.

I tried changing the variables to uppercase, which seems to be common practice here, but the stub generator doesn't want to respect that. The labels need to be i, j, k to match the Wikipedia article and probably every other explanatory text that's ever been produced on the subject, so I'm not really sure what to do at this point. Is _i, _j, _k too crazy?
Wait, do other languages not work that way by default? I can change it to the rounded number very easily.

I'm so sorry, it looks like the stub generator is wrong. I don't think I actually used that in code, so I'll add a check after I fix it to make sure the dimensions are respected.

Edit: All done. Thank you so much for pointing this out!
I'll have to figure out why I'm not getting notifications, thank you.
I haven't used it either, thanks!

I think Python's print is more of an exception in this regard. There are languages that would print just 8 for a float value of 8.0. Of course it is just an extra line to correct it in such languages, so I am not sure if you really want to change this (E.g. it is an easy puzzle and some beginner pythoners would have trouble printing 8 instead of 8.0). 
I just wanted to point out I don't like if a puzzle is too much designed only for Python in mind. Maybe let's wait for 3rd party opinion. I like the puzzle and willing to approve later.

Okay I gave another thought and I don't mind the output format anymore. In the meantime I also solved the puzzle to check if everything is fine, so I push on approve, a 3rd approval is still needed anyhow.
Maybe you can leave the variable names unchanged (i.e. kept in lowercase) in all sections except that you use _i, _j, _k in the stub generator?
D'oh, the stub generator doesn't like underscores _any_where_.
Hmmm… I think the revised version right now is the best you can do. No worries. Thanks.
